MEMBER'S PROTEST AGAINST SPEAKER'S
RULING THROUGH PRESS
(Announcement by Mr Speaker)


    Mr Speaker: It is my duty to direct the attention of the Assembly, in its capacity as guardian of the prestige of the Speaker, to a report of a statement purported to have been made by the Honourable Member for Queenstown to the Singapore Standard and reported in that paper of the 27th of November, 1958, under the caption:

"Mr Lee & new Chief Justice's appointment
He protests against Speaker's ruling"

Reference in the article is made to two questions disallowed by me as being inadmissible, one on the appointment of the Chief Justice for Singapore and the other on the proposal to abolish Teochew, Hainanese, Khek and Foochow radio programmes.

    The article, inter alia, states:

    'Mr Lee said that it had been the usual practice for the Speaker to give reasons whenever he ruled questions as "inadmissible".

Column: 1024



    "In this case, no reason had been given", he added.'

    At the outset it is my duty to point out that action of the nature reported to have been taken by the Honourable Member in protesting against the ruling of the Speaker through the Press is not only discourteous but also improper, the more so in the light of the implication of a sinister motive contained in the passage quoted by me.

    I am glad to be able to say, however, that the Honourable Member has assured me that he did not intend to be discourteous or improper. He further assures me that he told the reporter concerned that he accepted my rulings but was disappointed that the questions could not be tabled. Had he desired to protest he would have protested, as he is entitled to do, to me direct and not through the medium of the Press. He would then, of course, have been informed of the reasons for my rulings.

    Honourable Members are, I am sure, aware that if they are dissatisfied with the rulings of the Speaker, the proper course would be to raise the matter with the Speaker direct in an interview or by letter, and if thereafter they are still dissatisfied, their remedy is by way of substantive motions for review.

    I may add that although the relevant Standing Order in regard to questions does not provide that reasons should be given for any ruling, I have for the convenience of Members directed the Clerk to revive the practice of acquainting Honourable Members with the reasons for any adverse ruling to enable them all the better to decide whether they will or will not raise the matter with the Speaker.

CHINESE RACE IN SINGAPORE
(Breakdown Figures)


    1. Mr Lim Cher Kheng asked the Chief Secretary to state the latest approximate estimated number of persons in Singapore who are Hokkien, Cantonese, Teochew, Hakka, Hainanese and Foochow.

    Mr E. B. David: Sir, the figures approximately are Hokkien, 432,000; Cantonese, 236,000; Teochew, 234,000; Hakka, 60,000; Hainanese, 79,000; Foochow, 14,000.

RADIO BROADCAST OF CHINESE PROGRAMMES


    2. Mr Lim Cher Kheng asked the Chief Secretary whether he is aware of the strong opposition of the various Chinese community associations and guilds of Singapore to the Government's decision to discontinue using the Teochew, Hakka, Hainanese and Foochow dialects in the local broadcast of the Chinese, programme from January 1959, and whether the Government will reconsider this decision.

    Mr David: Sir, the Government has received a number of representations in this matter. As I informed the House on 5th November, the aim of the Government in making these changes is solely to improve the balance and content of the present Chinese broadcast programmes and advice was sought from several representative bodies and individuals before the decision was taken in agreement with the Government of the Federation of Malaya. Nevertheless, I welcome the opportunity of giving more details of what is proposed, since I think it will be seen that the apprehensions underlying these representations are largely without foundation. No changes will be made in the cultural contributions made by the four communities in question to the Chinese broadcasts. The opera, music and songs will continue as before and, in particular, the Teochew story-teller and those of the other dialects will remain on the air. The only major practical change will be to cut out the regular news bulletins in these dialects. The present practice of broadcasting the news bulletins in seven different dialects means that, out of a total weekly programme of 83½ hours, no less than 10½ hours is consumed in the repetition of news bulletins. Moreover, since these have to be broadcast at fixed times of the day, it leaves little flexibility for periodical adjustments and improvements in the cultural programmes. I

Column: 1026

should add that in times of emergency, arrangements would always be made for important announcements to be given in as many dialects as possible.

    Finally, Sir, I should mention two other improvements which it is proposed to make from 1st January. All Chinese programmes will from that date be broadcast on a single frequency. This will save listeners having to retune their sets in the course of listening to the programmes. Moreover, the total weekly hours of Chinese broadcasts will be slightly increased.

    Mr Lee Kuan Yew (Tanjong Pagar): Do we understand from that explanation, Sir, that the primary reason is to save broadcasting time and not to save cost?

    Mr David: Sir, the main object is to save time in order to give more time for cultural broadcasts.

    Mr Lee Kuan Yew: Do we understand from the statement that in times of emergency there will be broadcasts in all dialects, and that in fact the staff necessary for broadcasting in all dialects will still be there?

    Mr David: I do not expect that there will he any difficulty in making the necessary arrangements.

    Mr Lee Kuan Yew: Does that mean that as and when they are required, they will be ferretted out, but that there will be no maintenance of constant staff?

    Mr David: I would like notice of that question, Sir.

    Mr Lee Choon Eng (Queenstown): Is the Chief Secretary prepared to give an opportunity to this House to have a debate on this issue before implementing that decision?

    Mr David: I do not think that sufficient reason has been shown, Sir, to justify that.

    Mr Lim Cher Kheng (Changi): Mr Speaker, Sir, according to the Chief Secretary's report, the figure for Teochew is 234,000 and that for Hakka is 60,000. Leaving out the Hainanese and

Column: 1027

Foochow, will the Chief Secretary accept the fact that in this quarter of a million and over population there are many illiterates who cannot write or read in either Chinese or Malay, and therefore they cannot read the daily newspaper? So the only source of information that they can get is either through Radio Malaya or Rediffusion, sitting in a coffee-shop or somewhere else to listen. Since the Chief Secretary has assured us that during an emergency they are going to announce in all the other dialects, why not issue a daily news bulletin for these people so that they can enjoy getting the new bulletins through their own dialects?

    Mr David: Sir, I am advised that a person speaking in the Teochew dialect can converse perfectly easily with a person speaking in the Hokkien dialect -

    Mr Lee Choon Eng: No.

    Mr David: - and that, in fact, 80 per cent of the words used are the same.

    Mr Lee Choon Eng: Sir, since the Chief Secretary is not prepared to have a debate, is he aware that this is a very important issue and that it has caused great concern to the four Chinese communities in Singapore?

GOVERNMENT TUBERCULOSIS SURVEY
(Statistics)


    4. Mr John Ede asked the Minister for Health whether he will state-

    (a) the total number of persons who have been X-rayed under the Government Tuberculosis Survey;

    (b) what percentage of these persons showed evidence of tuberculosis, both healed and active;

    (c) what percentage of these persons have been found to require active treatment; and

    (d) whether there is a waiting list for the admission of infecting tuberculosis cases to hospital, including cases not discovered by the Survey.

    Mr Braga: Mr Speaker, Sir, in reply to (a), a total of 54,829 persons were X-rayed.

    With regard to (b), the percentage varies with the locality surveyed. In the Jalan Sultan area where 20,288 residents were X-rayed, the percentage of persons showing evidence of tuberculosis both healed and active was 13.2. In the Chinatown area, of a total of 20,742 residents X-rayed, the percentage was 15.4. In the Bukit Panjang area, of a total of 5,168 X-rayed, the percentage was 7.2, and in the Geylang Serai area, of a total of 4,474 X-rayed, the percentage was 7.4.

    With regard to (c), Sir, it is regretted that it is not possible to give a full answer because a full assessment has not been completed. Only in the Jalan Sultan area have investigations been substantially completed and, in consequence, it is possible only to give figures in that particular area. The percentage of those found to be suffering in the area from active tuberculosis is estimated to be 3.5. The reason for this estimate is this. From the Jalan Sultan area, 662 persons are now under treatment. That gives a percentage of 3.26, but of the 13.2, that is 2,675 persons,

Column: 1029

called for assessment, 219 have not yet turned up. We are trying to trace them by domiciliary service. An allowance therefore has to be made for those persons who might require treatment out of the 219 not yet assessed. That is why, Sir, we are giving an estimate of 3.5 instead of 3.26. Of these 662 persons, 213 were found to require hospital treatment, that is less than a third of those requiring treatment.

    With regard to (d), there are about 850 persons on the waiting list. This includes some 56 cases found in the survey from all the four areas and, while on the waiting list, they are receiving out-patient treatment. It often happens that when one's turn arrives one's condition has so improved, Sir, that hospitalization becomes unnecessary.

    Mr John Ede (Tanglin): Mr Speaker, Sir, it is a fact that a total of 80,000 persons were to have been X-rayed at the four centres, but will the Minister state why this figure fell short by about approximately 25,000?

    Mr Braga: Mr Speaker, Sir, it must be realised that the figures quoted refer only to residents in the area under survey. There are some 4,000 persons X-rayed additionally. They came from places other than the area surveyed, and those X-rays were not refused.

    Mr John Ede: The Minister has not answered my question. The original intention of the Government, as I understand it, was to make a survey in the four areas affected, of 20,000 in each area, making 80,000 altogether. We have been given figures of approximately 55,000 leaving a shortage of 25,000, and is this therefore making a survey less accurate than otherwise it should be?

    Mr Braga: Sir, the survey was conducted by the experts and the target, that I announced sometime ago was 50,000, intended by Government for the purposes of the survey.

FURTHER MEASURES AGAINST TUBERCULOSIS


    5. Mr John Ede asked the Minister for Health whether he will make a statement on what further measures the Government proposes to take in the campaign against tuberculosis in the light of the findings of the Government Tuberculosis Survey.

    Mr Braga: Until the financial position becomes clearer and the full facts of the Survey are available, I am not as yet in a position to formulate with any definiteness further measures. But the whole matter will certainly be reviewed.

    Mr John Ede: Mr Speaker, Sir, in view of the fact that there will be more cases of tuberculosis requiring hospitalization, in addition to those already on the waiting list mentioned as 850, will the Minister please explain why it has been decided to change a T.B. ward into a Nurses' hostel?

    Mr Braga: Mr Speaker, Sir, I think the hon. Member does not remember what was said here in the debate on the 1958 Estimates. At page 421, the House approved only $1,000 with which to construct a Nurses' hostel and training school, although the estimated cost is $2-million, the reason being that it was then beyond the building capacity of the Public Works Department.

    With regard to the use of the present wards for training of hospital nurses, I do not mind admitting that there is a shortage of staff. It was found necessary for the present to get the number of our trained assistant nurses up to scratch.

    Mr John Ede: Mr Speaker, Sir, may I remind the Minister that only last month we sanctioned $62,000 to convert, a T.B. ward into a Nurses' hostel on the grounds that there was no need for extra beds for T.B. patients. Would he now explain what is meant by 850 on the waiting list?

    Mr Braga: Mr Speaker, Sir, I said that although these people are on the waiting list for treatment, very often by the time their turn comes, they have so improved that they do not need hospitalization.

    Mr John Ede: Mr Speaker, Sir, will the Government consider presenting a White Paper setting out the whole T.B. problem as revealed by the survey as a matter of public importance?

    Mr Braga: That will be duly considered.

    Mr Lee Kuan Yew: Mr Speaker, Sir, did I hear the Minister right? In effect he is suggesting that it is better to be outside the hospital waiting for your turn to get in, and recover before you get in, than to be inside the hospital receiving treatment?

    Mr Braga: I made no such suggestion, Sir, although I did say that those on the waiting list are being treated. In the Tan Tock Seng Hospital there are three wards each with a 34-bed capacity lying vacant, and the reason why we have not been able to use these beds is that there is a great shortage of nursing staff. One block of 206 beds, originally intended for T.B. patients, is used temporarily as a hostel and a school for the training of assistant nurses. This is a temporary measure. In order to meet the need of staff, we used part of the accommodation as a nursing school and hostel. Consideration has been given to the recruitment of nursing sisters from elsewhere.

IMPORT OF CHINA GOODS INTO SINGAPORE
(Effects of Suspension)


    7. Mr Lim Cher Kheng asked the Minister for Commerce and Industry whether he will make a statement on the effects of the suspension by China, as reported in the local press, of the import of certain goods into Singapore, and what steps does he propose to take to ensure that the entrepot trade of Singapore will not be jeopardised and that the cost of living in Singapore will not rise as a result of this suspension.

    Mr J. M. Jumabhoy: Sir, I have had no official intimation of any suspension of exports by China to Singapore. If, however, the reports in the newspapers of suspension of exports of certain preserves, salted vegetables and fruits are correct, it could create some difficulty in supplies for those who prefer these articles; but it is unlikely to have any significant effect on the cost of living as a whole. It might perhaps be beneficial by switching the taste preference of consumers to similar locally produced articles. It is also unlikely to have any significant effect on our entrepot trade, as indications show that not much of the above goods go into the entrepot trade stream and also because most of the goods required for our entrepot trade are freely available from other sources.

    Looking at the picture of China's trade as a whole with Singapore, we have been exporting to China much less than we have been importing from China. In short, the balance of trade is against us. Our total trade with China in January to September 1958 has been under four per cent of our total overseas trade.

    Sir, I must take the opportunity of correcting some misimpressions that might have been created in the minds of the people of Singapore -

    Mr Speaker: Order. I was wondering whether that statement would not arise on the adjournment, as I see that the hon. Member for Changi has obtained

    Mr Speaker: Please continue.

Jumabhoy: I must take this opportunity of correcting some mis-impressions that might have been created in the minds of the people of Singapore by certain statements alleged to have been made by trading agencies in China in their correspondence with Singapore merchants, as quoted in Press reports.

    It has been alleged that the reported suspension by China in certain lines of exports to Singapore resulted from certain discriminatory actions of the Singapore Government. The only action by Singapore which could be construed as such was the ban imposed last month at the request of the Federation Government on imports of certain types of textiles. The first and foremost duty of any elected Government in any country is to safeguard the economy of the country. As far as Singapore is concerned, the economy of Singapore and that of the Federation is so closely interlinked that any damage to the economy of the Federation is bound to have a much stronger repercussion in Singapore.

    If we are looking to a merger with the Federation, it is the clear duty of any Singapore Government to do its best to prevent the undermining of the Malayan economy. The step taken by the Singapore Government at the request of the Federation Government to temporarily safeguard their textile industry is not therefore a discriminatory step against China as such; but a step taken for the benefit of the Malayan economy as a whole. I can well conceive such a step being taken against any other country if it was considered necessary in the interests of our economy, bearing of course in mind any officially recognized contractual obligations.

    It might bear a little explaining why the step was taken against the particular types of textiles only from China. It is quite apparent that the trading policy of China is strongly influenced by political considerations, as is evidenced from the fact that China has been selling

Column: 1038

these goods below the comparative producing cost of countries like Japan, where there is a high degree of automation and labour is cheap. In fact, China has been able to underprice her goods even below the cost of Hongkong producers who have had at their command cheap refugee labour.

    It is apparent, therefore, that China's policy has been to dump its goods in certain markets at a price which has no bearing on the cost of production in order to undermine the industries of certain countries. This undercutting cannot, however, go on indefinitely without having an effect on China's economy, and it is possible that the present move may be due to the adverse economic results of the undercutting policies being felt in China.

    It is also possible that long-term credit arrangements may have been stretched too far and that China may be feeling that the time has come to stop these credit facilities and ask for cash payments.

    Mr Lim Cher Kheng: Nonsense!

    Mr J. M. Jumabhoy: Fair competition in trade has always been encouraged by the Singapore Government but where undercutting with political motives results in damage to the Malayan economy, the Government feels that it has an obligation to the Malayan economy as a whole, even though the particular industry concerned may be located in the Federation.

    In short, while the Singapore Government has no intention or wish to hamper trade between China and Singapore, it is its clear duty to see that such trade is not to the detriment of any of our industries or to the Malayan economy as a whole, and this not only applies to China but to any other country.

    To blame the Singapore Government in the fashion reported by the Press is therefore a clear indication of China's desire to make political capital out of what is purely a step dictated by economic necessity to Singapore as far as Singapore's action is concerned, and

LEAKAGES OF EXAMINATION QUESTIONS
(Statement by the Minister for Education)


10.30 a.m.

    The Minister for Education (Mr Chew Swee Kee): Mr Speaker, Sir, the black clouds that have gathered over my Ministry since 6th November, 1958, are only partially cleared, and I feel that it is my duty to make a statement on the part that is cleared so that the public can know the facts.

    I am referring to the two leakages of examination questions set by my Ministry in the English Secondary Schools Entrance Examination and the Government Chinese Senior Middle III examination. Of course, the public reaction to both leakages - especially when the second one followed the first one so closely - is that my head and the heads of my Ministry officials should be delivered on a charger to this House, in addition to a public enquiry.

    I can understand the concern of the people over these leakages because these examinations are national examinations. But, when serious things like this happen, we must keep calm and refrain from saying anything that might prejudice the issue before the truth is out.

    The English Secondary Schools' Entrance Examination is a stepping stone to secondary education which is much sought after, and for which there may be insufficient places for those who want it. The Government Chinese Senior Middle III examination is a national examination enabling those who pass it to obtain employment in the public service and to go for higher studies. SEAMEN
(Discrimination; Signing of agreements)


    7. Mr Seah Peng Chuan asked the Minister for Commerce and Industry whether -

    (a) the Seamen's Registry Board, in supplying registered seamen to employers, discriminates against seamen who are members of unions;

    (b) he will arrange for permission to be given for an official of the union to which a seaman belongs to be present when the seaman signs an "agreement with the crew"; and

    (c) he will arrange for a copy of such agreement to be provided to the seaman concerned.

    Mr J. M. Jumabhoy: The answers are:

    (a) Certainly not.

    (b) Union officials can be and are allowed to be present outside the counter in the Shipping Office when seamen are signing Articles of Agreement. Provided good reasons are furnished to the Shipping Office and upon written application by the seamen themselves, Union officials may be present behind the counter.

    (c) There is no legal provision for such a procedure, but the law does require however that the Agreement be read over and explained by the Port Officer to each seaman. At the commencement of every voyage, the Master is also bound by law to post up a legible copy of the Agreement in some part of the ship which is accessible to the crew. This arrangement is being observed and has been found to work very satisfactorily on all British ships since 1854 and conforms with international shipping practice.

    8. Mr Seah Peng Chuan asked the Minister for Commerce and Industry whether he will consider lifting the ban on the import of cottons into Singapore from China.

    Mr J. M. Jumabhoy: It will be recalled that when the Federation requested our co-operation in this matter it was for a period of three months pending the finalisation of the Federation's anti-dumping law to protect its industries. to improving trade relations and thereby increasing trade.
